description: A simple, nutritious, and flavorful Ugandan staple made by sautéing amaranth greens with onions and tomatoes until tender. It has a unique, slightly earthy and peppery flavor and a soft, silky texture.

cultural_significance.cultural_notes: Dodo is one of the most common and affordable leafy green vegetables in Uganda. It grows easily and is a vital source of vitamins and iron for many families. It's a dish found in almost every Ugandan household and local restaurant, served as a perfect accompaniment to starchy foods like Matoke, Posho, and Rice. Its simplicity and nutritional value make it a cornerstone of the local diet.

ingredients.name: Fresh Amaranth Greens (Dodo)
ingredients.notes: Thoroughly washed to remove soil, tough stems removed, and roughly chopped

steps.instruction: Wash the amaranth greens thoroughly in several changes of water to remove all grit and soil. Drain in a colander.
Remove any tough stems and roughly chop the leaves.
Heat the vegetable oil in a large pot or saucepan over medium heat. Add the sliced onion and sauté until soft and translucent, about 3-4 minutes.
Add the chopped tomatoes to the pot. Cook for 3-4 minutes, mashing them slightly with the spoon, until they soften and break down.
Add the chopped dodo to the pot. It will seem like a lot at first, but it will wilt down significantly.
Add the salt and 2 tablespoons of water. Stir everything together to combine the greens with the onion and tomato base.
Cover the pot and let it cook over medium-low heat for 5-7 minutes. The greens will steam and release their own water.

cooking_indicators.visual: The greens will wilt completely and turn a dark green color.
cooking_indicators.texture: The leaves should be very tender.

steps.instruction: Remove the lid and continue to cook, stirring occasionally, for another 2-3 minutes until most of the liquid has evaporated. Be careful not to let it burn.
Taste and adjust the salt if needed. The dodo should be tender, flavorful, and not watery.
Serve the dodo hot as a side dish.

serving_suggestions: A mandatory side dish for Posho (Ugali), Matoke (steamed bananas), Cassava, or Rice. It is always served alongside a main protein stew like beef, chicken, or beans.
